subject: Add Location and LocationType for resources
commitMessage:
Add Location and LocationType for resources

Added location_util::getLocation to help find the LocationCode interface
used for the ServiceLabel. It also looks for the Inventory.Connector.X
interfaces for the LocationType.

getLocation is divided into getLocationCode and getLocationType that can
be called separating for resources that already has structures to get
the location infos.

Removed the getLocation function in Processor and Manager and replaced
with the common location_util::getLocation instead.

```
Inventory.Connector.Embedded means LocationType of Embedded type.
```

The LocationType can be used to allow the client to determine the type
of connection for the current chassis.

Supporting
- Slot
- Embedded

Default to Slot.

The Embedded is added as part of location type
in https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/pull/4622 and not in official
release yet.

Tested:
Working but Embedded is not supported in an official release yet... no
other error with the validator.
```
*** /redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis0
         Type (#Chassis.v1_14_0.Chassis), GET SUCCESS (time: 0.077815)
Location.PartLocation.LocationType: Invalid Enum value 'Embedded' found, expected ['Slot', 'Bay', 'Connector', 'Socket', 'Backplane']
Thermal: The given property is deprecated by revision: This link has been deprecated in favor of the ThermalSubsystem link property.
Power: The given property is deprecated by revision: This link has been deprecated in favor of the PowerSubsystem link property.
          FAIL...
```

Chassis Example
```
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/board_0",
  "@odata.type": "#Chassis.v1_14_0.Chassis",
  "Actions": {
    "#Chassis.Reset": {
      "@Redfish.ActionInfo": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/board_0/ResetActionInfo",
      "target": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/warthog_1/Actions/Chassis.Reset"
    }
  },
  "ChassisType": "RackMount",
  "Id": "board_0",
  "Links": {
    "ComputerSystems": [
      {
        "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system"
      }
    ],
    "ManagedBy": [
      {
        "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc"
      }
    ],
  },
  "Location": {
    "PartLocation": {
      "LocationType": "Embedded",
      "ServiceLabel": "PEX"
    }
  },
...
}
```

Processor Example:
```
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Processors/processor0",
  "@odata.type": "#Processor.v1_11_0.Processor",
  "Id": "processor0",
  "Location": {
    "PartLocation": {
      "LocationType": "Embedded",
      "ServiceLabel": "PEX"
    }
  },
  "Name": "processor0",
  ...
}
```

Change-Id: Ibcbf2f26b4da96edbfa67c1dd367c9178037dcff
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>

Patch Set 14:

(2 comments)

Tested using QEMU by creating a chassis in the assettag.yaml file in phosphor-inventory-manager:

    - name: Creating Chassis at startup
      description: >
          Create /system/chassis at startup
      type: startup
      actions:
          - name: createObjects
            objs:
             /system/chassis:
                xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Chassis:
                  Type:
                    value: "RackMount1"
                    type: string
                xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Board:
                  Name:
                    value: "board1"
                    type: string
                  Probe:
                    value: "no probe"
                    type: string
                  Type:
                    value: "Board"
                    type: string
                xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Connector.Embedded:
                  Type:
                    value: "EmbeddedConnector"
                    type: string
                xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Connector.Slot:
                  Type:
                    value: "SlotConnector"
                    type: string
                xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Decorator.LocationCode:
                  LocationCode:
                    value: "IO1"
                    type: string

Then executed a request against BMCWeb:

    $ curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis|grep Location -a5
  % Total    % Received % Xferd  Average Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current
                                 Dload  Upload   Total   Spent    Left  Speed
100  1060  100  1060    0     0   3812      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--  3812
      {
        "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc"
      }
    ]
  },
  "Location": {
    "PartLocation": {
      "ServiceLabel": "IO1"
    }
  },
  "Name": "chassis",
  "PCIeDevices": {

It seems the mapping of the DBus LocationCode to RedFish Location and RedFish PhysicalLocation for the other resource types work in similar ways and this looks good to me.

Patch Set 21:

Lots of stuff going on here, not all of it mentioned in the commit message.  I suspect we need to get this broken up into:

1.  commit to move the code we use in Processor
2. One commit per schema to add the appropriate properties to each one, keeping in mind that some schemas don't have a LocationType, because they're not physical representations of the part, but the software representation of it.

Typo: type, Locationtype
Done

It seems PhysicalLocation is used for Drive while Location is used for the other resources (StorageController, Processor, Chassis, Storage), it appears this is because Location is deprecated for Drive, do we need to populate both Location and PhysicalLocation for now?

I think just using the Physical Location is fine for Drive.

Since Location was not used in Dive before I think it is fine not to include it and use the new one.

I still have to clean up this change a bit, but the main functionality should still be the same.

This has lifetime issues if the connection closes before the callback is complete (well, it could).

Please pass in a json key name or a json pointer by value instead of using a raw pointer here.  You already kind of do that with location and locationName.  This would effectively be combining them into a single value.

Done. I have used json_pointer now that I know about it.

Thanks.

Please take a look at how we generally do these conversions.  Building a map just to use it once is inefficient in both runtime and code size.  A simple if/else ladder compiles much smaller and is more efficient.
Done

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/02bdd9672c7619cc1e11fe3daed8e3ec092b207b/redfish-core/lib/processor.hpp#L621

This is repeated?

oh yeah, thanks. I have removed the duplicated code to use the new one instead.

There is another one in Manager.. so I also removed that one.
Need to handle the case where no path matches?
I just added a internal error if no path is found. Calling this function should always be able to find the path.
Please combine this mapper call such that all interfaces don't need to do 2 calls to the mapper to effect this utility function.

not exactly sure what you mean here?

Do you mean to remove this call and use the Mapper call in the resource that call this, instead of calling it here?

I'll try to clean it up that way.
yes.  that's exactly what I mean.
This doesn't seem right, not everything is a slot type.
why not just `else { return false; }` and then you can get rid of the std::optional?
You didn't ask the mapper for this interface, so does this path ever get hit?
Please don't use starts_with in this context.  It tends to lead to bugs, and is listed in Common errors.md.

This is in the managers resource, which by definition, is ALWAYS embedded.  In the DC-SCM case, it might be on a card, but it would still be embedded type, with the card being its own Chassis.  There's no need to do complex lookups here, and although embedded is correct, I'm not really sure what value this is adding to the redfish tree.  Maybe you could enumerate your use cases in the commit message.

Also, I see no testing of this mentioned.
Same as above.

I'm not really following how this is expected to work.  "StorageController" isn't a physical device, so how does it have a Location?  The chassis the storage controller is attached to might have a location, but there's no such thing as a socketted storage controller (in the redfish definition of storage controller).
This assumes there's one connection name for the drive.  You can't make that assumption, as the mapper for your interfaces, and parse them appropriately.
